docs.lead_paragraph: Last Tuesday's article on end-of-life care referred to work sheets to help people determine the treatment they want if they become gravely ill and can no longer make decisions. The work sheets, called ''The Medical Directive,'' were created by Dr. Linda L. Emanuel, former vice president for ethics at the American Medical Association and now director of a program in professionalism and human rights at Northwestern University Medical Center, and her husband, Dr. Ezekiel J. Emanuel, a bioethicist. The directive can be obtained at www.medicaldirective.org, or by calling (800) 214-4553.

headline.main: How to Get End-of-Life Work Sheets

docs.abstract: Source for work sheets for end-of-life care noted; photo (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: When Eva Peron, the first lady of Argentina, underwent a hysterectomy in November 1951, she did not know that her husband, Juan, had summoned a Manhattan cancer surgeon to perform the procedure. The surgeon, Dr. George T. Pack, flew to Buenos Aires, entered the operating room after Eva was anesthetized, and left before she awoke. A month earlier, using the same secret ritual, Dr. Pack examined an anesthetized Eva to confirm the cervical cancer that Argentine doctors had detected.

headline.main: From the Life of Evita, a New Chapter on Medical Secrecy

docs.abstract: Dr Lawrence K Altman The Doctor's World article discusses revelations that Eva Peron was never told that she had cervical cancer, disease that killed her in July 1952; photo; she also did not know that surgery on her was performed by American cancer specialist, late Dr George T Pack; secrecy about cancer that was commonplace until recently discussed (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Annals of Internal Medicine is not the kind of a journal where one is likely to find advertisements in the back for healing crystals or testimonials to the healing power of the latest herbal craze. So some may be a little surprised to see an article in today's issue suggesting that there may be merit to an alternative form of medicine known as distance healing. This can include anything from therapeutic touch -- in which practitioners, without touching their patients, try to alter their energy fields -- to simply praying for people who are ill.
docs.abstract: Dr John A Aston reports on study suggesting efficacy of 'distance healing,' alternative form of medicine that can involve anything from therapeutic touch to praying for people who are ill (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Cocaine is indisputably addictive, but while many fall into its hold, others simply dabble and move on. To date, predicting how a user will react to the drug has been anyone's guess. A new study, however, suggests that one sign of the future addict is plunging headlong into cocaine use from the very beginning.

headline.main: Of Rats, Cocaine and Addiction Mysteries

docs.abstract: Yale University study suggests that one sign of future drug addict is plunging headlong into cocaine use from initial exposure (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Evolution has not always come up with things people consider wonderful. Note mosquitoes, sickle cell anemia and the killer instinct. But according to evolutionary theory, there is a reason for everything that has evolved. However obnoxious it may seem, somehow it enhances survival. And so it seems that survival is the likely reason for morning sickness, survival not just of the unborn child but also of the pregnant woman who must bear the burden of its prenatal development. That is the conclusion of two Cornell University evolutionary biologists after examining the results of nearly 80,000 successful and unsuccessful pregnancies, correlating their findings with the incidence of morning sickness and the development during early pregnancy of food aversions and cravings.

headline.main: What Could Be Good About Morning Sickness? Plenty

docs.abstract: Jane Brody Personal Health article on research suggesting that morning sickness so common in early pregnancy is actually body's way of keeping women away from potentially contamined foods at time when fetus is especially vulnerable; Samuel M Flaxman and Dr Paul W Sherman of Cornell report that nausea and vomiting helps protect both mother and fetus from toxins that can lurk in in meat, fish, poultry and eggs, which are also foods to which pregnant women develop most aversions; women who suffer from morning sickness also have fewer miscarriages; graphs (M)
docs.snippet: Evolution has not always come up with things people consider wonderful. Note mosquitoes, sickle cell anemia and the killer instinct. But according to evolutionary theory, there is a reason for everything that has evolved. However obnoxious it may...

docs.lead_paragraph: Considering how hard it is for many people to remember what they did even the day before, it is remarkable that so many childhood memories remain intact. But now a new study shows that many of those memories may be, at best, suspect.

headline.main: The Memories of Youth, Fading Fast

docs.abstract: Northwestern University researchers revisit study they did in 1960's of 73 boys, asking questions about their lives, and find that same individuals, now in their 40's, recall their teen years very differently (S)
docs.snippet: Considering how hard it is for many people to remember what they did even the day before, it is remarkable that so many childhood memories remain intact.    But now a new study shows that many of those memories may be, at best, suspect.

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Susie Orbach -- the therapist who treated Diana, Princess of Wales, for her eating disorders; the founder of the Women's Therapy Center of London; a former columnist for The Guardian; a visiting professor at the London School of Economics; and the author of 1978 best-seller ''Fat is a Feminist Issue'' -- is, aside from Sigmund Freud, probably the most famous psychotherapist to have ever set up couch in Britain. On a recent visit to New York, Dr. Orbach, 53, talked about her eighth book, ''The Impossibility of Sex: Stories of the Intimate Relationship Between Therapist and Patient'' (Scribner).

headline.main: Sex and the Therapist: Views of the Couch

docs.abstract: Well-known British therapist Dr Susie Orbach discusses emotional relationships between patient and psychotherapist, subject of her new book the Impossibility of Sex; interview; photo; Orbach also comments on late Princess Diana, whom she treated (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: It is easy to become irritated with the plodding pace of clinical medical science. Studies churn on for years, comparing Drug A with Drug B, Drug C with placebo, finally spitting out a few cautious conclusions that invariably end with a call for yet more research on more minutiae of the same old questions. Even doctors become impatient with it all. Sometimes, especially as they get older, they just begin to pay the studies less mind, and concentrate instead on what they have seen with their own eyes. At conferences they tend to lean their aging bones back in the chair and say to the young ones, ''I know all about those studies of A, B and C, and in my experience things are a little different.''

headline.main: It Can Pay To Ignore Experience

docs.abstract: Dr Abigail Zuger Cases column says that while wisdom of medical experience can be delicious to accumulate and display, it can also be quite dangerous; gives example of patient who had HIV and developed hepatitis (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Although he spent the first 17 years of his life on the shores of the Chesapeake Bay, Carl Immel had never set foot in its water. After being jailed on assault and theft charges two years ago, however, the court assigned Mr. Immel to Baltimore's Fresh Start Program, which uses sailing as a therapeutic tool for troubled teenagers. Soon he was racing a 23-foot Rainbow sail boat in Baltimore Harbor. ''I didn't know a jib from a main sheet,'' said Mr. Immel, now 19, who has since graduated from the program and gotten a job. ''But I loved it the first time I raced, especially being out there away from everything.''

headline.main: Youths Get a Dose of Salt-Water Therapy

docs.abstract: Baltimore's Fresh Start program uses sailing as therapeutic tool for troubled teen-agers from tough urban backgrounds; photo (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Researchers say they have been able to measure brain changes in dyslexic children who have been taught to read with a newly developed technique. Using an imaging device known as a spectroscope, researchers at the University of Washington examined the children before they took part in the study and found that the dyslexic children used four times as much brain energy to process sounds as did children without the disorder. After about a year of training, they used just 1.8 times as much energy.
docs.abstract: University of Washington researchers report on measurement of brain changes in dyslexic children who have been taught to read with newly developed technique, which links reading instruction to hands-on activities (S)
